content.name: Basic Profile for Period
content.description: Basic Profile for Period for validation support

definition.short: Time range defined by start and end date/time
definition.formal: A time period defined by a start and end date and optionally time.
definition.comments: This is not a duration - that's a measure of time (a separate type), but a duration that occurs at a fixed value of time. A Period specifies a range of time; the context of use will specify whether the entire range applies (e.g. "the patient was an inpatient of the hospital for this time range") or one value from the range applies (e.g. "give to the patient between these two times"). If a duration might be required, specify the type as Interval|Duration.

constraint.name: Start <= End
constraint.human: If present, start SHALL have a lower value than end

mapping.map: IVL<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"] or URG<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"]

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
definition.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

definition.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
definition.formal: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.
definition.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.

content.name: Basic Profile for Coding
content.description: Basic Profile for Coding for validation support

definition.short: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system
definition.formal: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
definition.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.

constraint.name: Value set doesn't substitute for system
constraint.human: If a valueSet is provided, a system URI Is required

mapping.map: CE/CNE/CWE subset one of the sets of component 1-3 or 4-6

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
definition.comments: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.

definition.short: Version of the system - if relevant
definition.formal: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and When the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.

definition.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
definition.formal: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

definition.short: If this code was chosen directly by the user
definition.formal: Indicates that this code was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
definition.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations.

definition.short: Set this coding was chosen from
definition.formal: The set of possible coded values this coding was chosen from or constrained by.

content.name: Basic Profile for Range
content.description: Basic Profile for Range for validation support

definition.short: Set of values bounded by low and high
definition.formal: A set of ordered Quantities defined by a low and high limit.
definition.comments: The stated low and high value are assumed to have arbitrarily high precision when it comes to determining which values are in the range. I.e. 1.99 is not in the range 2 -> 3.

constraint.name: No Range flag on Quantity
constraint.human: Quantity values cannot have a comparator when used in a Range

constraint.name: Low < high
constraint.human: If present, low SHALL have a lower value than high

mapping.map: NR and also possibly SN (but see also quantity)

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: The low limit. The boundary is inclusive.
definition.comments: If the low element is missing, the low boundary is not known.

definition.formal: The high limit. The boundary is inclusive.
definition.comments: If the high element is missing, the high boundary is not known.

content.name: Basic Profile for Quantity
content.description: Basic Profile for Quantity for validation support

definition.formal: A measured amount (or an amount that can potentially be measured). Note that measured amounts include amounts that are not precisely quantified, including amounts involving arbitrary units and floating currencies.
definition.comments: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.

constraint.name: SHALL have a system
constraint.human: If a code for the units is present, the system SHALL also be present

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
definition.comments: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).

mapping.map: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

definition.formal: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues. E.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
definition.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value.

definition.formal: A human-readable form of the units.

definition.short: System that defines coded unit form
definition.formal: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit.
A computer processable form of the units in some unit representation system.
definition.comments:
The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.

The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system (Unless the Quantity element has a dataAbsentReason flag).

content.name: Basic Profile for Attachment
content.description: Basic Profile for Attachment for validation support

definition.short: Content in a format defined elsewhere
definition.formal: For referring to data content defined in other formats.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.short: Mime type of the content, with charset etc.
definition.formal: Identifies the type of the data in the attachment and allows a method to be chosen to interpret or render the data. Includes mime type parameters such as charset where appropriate.

mapping.map: ED.2+ED.3/RP.2+RP.3. Note conversion may be needed if old style values are being used

definition.formal: The human language of the content. The value can be any valid value according to BCP 47.
The actual data of the attachment - a sequence of bytes. In XML, represented using base64.
definition.comments: The base64-encoded data SHALL be expressed in the same character set as the base resource XML or JSON.

definition.short: Uri where the data can be found
definition.formal: An alternative location where the data can be accessed.
definition.comments: If both data and url are provided, the url SHALL point to the same content as the data contains. Urls may be relative references or may reference transient locations such as a wrapping envelope using cid: though this has ramifications for using signatures. Relative URLs are interpreted relative to the service url, like a resource reference, rather than relative to the resource itself. If a URL is provided, it SHALL resolve to actual data.

mapping.map: RP.1+RP.2 - if they refer to a URL (see v2.6)

definition.short: Number of bytes of content (if url provided)
definition.formal: The number of bytes of data that make up this attachment.
definition.comments: The number of bytes is redundant if the data is provided as a base64binary, but is useful if the data is provided as a url reference.

definition.formal: The calculated hash of the data using SHA-1. Represented using base64.

definition.short: Label to display in place of the data
definition.formal: A label or set of text to display in place of the data.

content.name: Basic Profile for Ratio
content.description: Basic Profile for Ratio for validation support

definition.short: A ratio of two Quantity values - a numerator and a denominator
definition.formal: A relationship of two Quantity values - expressed as a numerator and a denominator.

constraint.name: both numerator and denominator
constraint.human: numerator and denominator SHALL both be present, or both be absent

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: The value of the numerator.
The value of the denominator.

content.name: Basic Profile for SampledData
content.description: Basic Profile for SampledData for validation support

definition.short: A series of measurements taken by a device
definition.formal: A series of measurements taken by a device, with upper and lower limits. There may be more than one dimension in the data.
definition.comments: The data is not interpretable without at least origin, period, and dimensions, but these are optional to allow a separation between the template of measurement and the actual measurement, such as between DeviceCapabilities and DeviceLog.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: The base quantity that a measured value of zero represents. In addition, this provides the units of the entire measurement series.
The length of time between sampling times, measured in milliseconds.
definition.comments: This is usually a whole number.

definition.short: Multiply data by this before adding to origin
definition.formal: A correction factor that is applied to the sampled data points before they are added to the origin.
The lower limit of detection of the measured points. This is needed if any of the data points have the value "L" (lower than detection limit).
The upper limit of detection of the measured points. This is needed if any of the data points have the value "U" (higher than detection limit).

definition.short: Number of sample points at each time point
definition.formal: The number of sample points at each time point. If this value is greater than one, then the dimensions will be interlaced - all the sample points for a point in time will be recorded at once.
definition.comments: If there is more than one dimension, the code for the type of data will define the meaning of the dimensions (typically ECG data).

definition.formal: A series of data points which are decimal values separated by a single space (character u20). The special values "E" (error), "L" (below detection limit) and "U" (above detection limit) can also be used in place of a decimal value.

content.name: Basic Profile for ResourceReference
content.description: Basic Profile for ResourceReference for validation support

definition.short: A reference from one resource to another
definition.formal: A reference from one resource to another.

constraint.name: Inline
constraint.human: SHALL have a local reference if the resource is provided inline

mapping.map: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.short: Relative, internal or absolute URL reference
definition.formal: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
definition.comments:
Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries. 

Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the url conforms to the structure "/[type]/@[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

definition.formal: Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
definition.comments: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

content.name: Basic Profile for CodeableConcept
content.description: Basic Profile for CodeableConcept for validation support

definition.short: Concept - reference to a terminology or just  text
definition.formal: A concept that may be defined by a formal reference to a terminology or ontology or may be provided by text.
definition.comments: Not all terminology uses fit this general pattern. In some cases, models should not use CodeableConcept and use Coding directly and provide their own structure for managing text, codings, translations and the relationship between elements and pre- and post-coordination.

constraint.name: Coding.primary rule
constraint.human: Only one coding in a set can be chosen directly by the user

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.short: Code defined by a terminology system
definition.formal: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
definition.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL not be used to infer meaning.

definition.short: Plain text representation of the concept
definition.formal: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
definition.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

content.name: Basic Profile for Identifier
content.description: Basic Profile for Identifier for validation support

definition.formal: A technical identifier - identifies some entity uniquely and unambiguously.

mapping.map: II - see see identifier pattern at http://wiki.hl7.org/index.php?title=Common_Design_Patterns#Identifier_Pattern for relevant discussion. The Identifier class is a little looser than the v3 type II because it allows URIs as well as registered OIDs or GUIDs
CX / EI (occasionally, more often EI maps to a resource id or a URL)

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: The purpose of this identifier.
definition.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one. Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.

mapping.map: N/A - this is sometimes implied by context

definition.formal: A text string for the identifier that can be displayed to a human so they can recognize the identifier.

mapping.map: N/A - this is sometimes implied by context

definition.formal: Establishes the namespace in which set of possible id values is unique.
The portion of the identifier typically displayed to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
definition.comments: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID

definition.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
definition.formal: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

mapping.map: N/A - this is sometimes implied by context

definition.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
definition.formal: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
definition.comments: The reference may be just a text description of the assigner.

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field

content.name: Basic Profile for Extension
content.description: Basic Profile for Extension for validation support

definition.short: Optional Extensions Element - found in all resources.
definition.formal: Optional Extensions Element - found in all resources.

definition.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
definition.formal: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
definition.comments: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition should be version specific.  This will ideally be the URI for the Resource Profile defining the extension, with the code for the extension after a #.

definition.formal: Value of extension - may be a resource or one of a constrained set of the data types (see Extensibility in the spec for list).

content.name: Basic Profile for Narrative
content.description: Basic Profile for Narrative for validation support

definition.short: A human-readable formatted text, including images
definition.formal: A human-readable formatted text, including images.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. definition.formal: The status of the narrative - whether it's entirely generated (from just the defined data or the extensions too), or whether a human authored it and it may contain additional data.
The actual narrative content, a stripped down version of XHTML.
definition.comments: The contents of the html element are an XHTML fragment containing only the basic html formatting elements described in chapters 7-11 and 15 of the HTML 4.0 standard, <a> elements (either name or href), images and internally contained stylesheets. The XHTML content may not contain a head, a body, external stylesheet references, scripts, forms, base/link/xlink, frames, iframes and objects.

constraint.human: The narrative SHALL contain only the basic html formatting attributes described in chapters 7-11 (except section 4 of chapter 9) and 15 of the HTML 4.0 standard, <a> elements (either name or href), images and internally contained style attributes
The narrative SHALL have some non-whitespace content

The narrative SHALL contain only the basic html formatting elements described in chapters 7-11 (except section 4 of chapter 9) and 15 of the HTML 4.0 standard, <a> elements (either name or href), images and internally contained style attributes

content.name: Basic Profile for Schedule
content.description: Basic Profile for Schedule for validation support

definition.short: A schedule that specifies an event that may occur multiple times
definition.formal: Specifies an event that may occur multiple times. Schedules are used for to reord when things are expected or requested to occur.
definition.comments: A schedule can be either a list of events - intervals on which the event occurs, or a single event with repeating criteria or just repeating criteria with no actual event.

constraint.name: Multiple or repeating events
constraint.human: There can only be a repeat element if there is none or one event

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: Identifies specific time periods when the event should occur.

definition.short: Only if there is none or one event
definition.formal: Identifies a repeating pattern to the intended time periods.
definition.comments: If present, the Schedule.event indicates the time of the first occurrence.

constraint.name: End condition
constraint.human: At most, only one of count or end can be present

constraint.name: Repeat cycle
constraint.human: Either frequency or when SHALL be present, but not both

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.short: Event occurs frequency times per duration
definition.formal: Indicates how often the event should occur.

definition.short: HS | WAKE | AC | ACM | ACD | ACV | PC | PCM | PCD | PCV - common life events
definition.formal: Identifies the occurrence of daily life that determines timing.
How long each repetition should last.

constraint.name: Duration Positive
constraint.human: duration SHALL be a positive value

definition.short: s | min | h | d | wk | mo | a - unit of time (UCUM)
definition.formal: The units of time for the duration.
A total count of the desired number of repetitions.
definition.comments: An end need not be specified.

definition.formal: When to stop repeating the schedule.
definition.comments: An end need not be specified.

content.name: Basic Profile for Contact
content.description: Basic Profile for Contact for validation support

definition.short: Technology mediated contact details (phone, fax, email, etc)
definition.formal: All kinds of technology mediated contact details for a person or organization, including telephone, email, etc.

constraint.name: System is required
constraint.human: A system is required if a value is provided.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: Telecommunications form for contact - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.
The actual contact details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
definition.comments: Additional out of band data such as extensions, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value.

definition.short: home | work | temp | old | mobile - purpose of this address
definition.formal: Identifies the purpose for the address.
definition.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old contact etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.

mapping.map: XTN.2 - but often indicated by field

definition.short: Time period when the contact was/is in use
definition.formal: Time period when the contact was/is in use.

content.name: Basic Profile for Address
content.description: Basic Profile for Address for validation support

definition.formal: There is a variety of postal address formats defined around the world. This format defines a superset that is the basis for all addresses around the world.
definition.comments: Note: address is for postal addresses, not physical locations.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.short: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address
definition.formal: The purpose of this address.
definition.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.

definition.formal: A full text representation of the address.
definition.comments: Can provide both a text representation and parts.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

definition.short: Street name, number, direction & P.O. Box etc
definition.formal:
This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction, 
P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)

definition.formal: The name of the city, town, village or other community or delivery center.
Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (i.e. US 2 letter state codes).
A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.
Country - a nation as commonly understood or generally accepted.
definition.comments: ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a full country name.

definition.short: Time period when address was/is in use
definition.formal: Time period when address was/is in use.

content.name: Basic Profile for HumanName
content.description: Basic Profile for HumanName for validation support

definition.short: Name of a human - parts and usage
definition.formal: A human's name with the ability to identify parts and usage.
definition.comments: Names may be changed, or repudiated, or people may have different names in different contexts. Names may be divided into parts of different type that have variable significance depending on context, though the division into parts does not always matter. With personal names, the different parts may or may not be imbued with some implicit meaning; various cultures associate different importance with the name parts and the degree to which systems must care about name parts around the world varies widely.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.short: usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
definition.formal: Identifies the purpose for this name.
definition.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old name etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a name is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.

mapping.map: XPN.7, but often indicated by which field contains the name

definition.short: Text representation of the full name
definition.formal: A full text representation of the name.
definition.comments: Can provide both a text representation and structured parts.

definition.formal: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
definition.comments: For family name, hyphenated names such as "Smith-Jones" are a single name, but names with spaces such as "Smith Jones" are broken into multiple parts.

definition.short: Given names (not always 'first'). Includes middle names
definition.formal: Given name.
definition.comments: If only initials are recorded, they may be used in place of the full name.  Not called "first name" since given names do not always come first.

definition.short: Parts that come before the name
definition.formal: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the start of the name.

definition.short: Parts that come after the name
definition.formal: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the end of the name.

definition.short: Time period when name was/is in use
definition.formal: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.

content.name: Profile for Age on Quantity
content.description: Basic Profile for Age on Quantity for validation support

definition.formal: A measured amount (or an amount that can potentially be measured). Note that measured amounts include amounts that are not precisely quantified, including amounts involving arbitrary units and floating currencies.
definition.comments: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.

constraint.name: SHALL have a system
constraint.human: If a code for the units is present, the system SHALL also be present

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
definition.comments: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).

mapping.map: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

definition.formal: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues. E.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
definition.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value.

definition.formal: A human-readable form of the units.

definition.short: System that defines coded unit form
definition.formal: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit.
A computer processable form of the units in some unit representation system.
definition.comments:
The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.

The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system (Unless the Quantity element has a dataAbsentReason flag).
